In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  2009  technical  assistance  (TA)  program  of  the  Regional  and  Sustainable 
Development Department (RSDD) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) includes a regional 
capacity development TA project to undertake analytical work on issues related to the facilitation 
of infrastructure investment in Asia. The large need for the efficient formulation and financing of 
urban infrastructure is to be addressed under ADB’s long-term strategic framework 2008–2020 
(Strategy 2020)1 and is an important issue for developing member countries (DMCs). Thus, this 
TA project2 responds to both the demands of DMCs and the operational needs of ADB. The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Urban economies play a central role in Asia’s economic growth and development. Well-
managed cities act as engines of economic growth, bind national economies with the world 
economy, and become symbols of national pride. However, such a role depends on the efficient 
provision  of  infrastructure.  When  infrastructure  conditions  in  urban  areas  are  poor,  cities 
become  bottlenecks  to  growth,  hindering  regional  and  global  economic  integration  and 
frustrating efforts to reduce poverty. Many urban areas also play key service center roles in the 
national economy, and infrastructure linking them to rural areas plays a vital role in rural poverty 
reduction. 
3.  Financing of this infrastructure is a key constraint to Asia’s economic development and 
progress in poverty reduction. The scale of funding is beyond governments and development 
assistance. Improved systems for infrastructure finance are required to provide the levels of 
infrastructure—crucially providing a platform for private sector participation. ADB has identified 
infrastructure as a key focus of its Strategy 2020. ADB’s urban community of practice has 
identified financing of urban infrastructure as a key area in its new business development efforts 
supporting the implementation of Strategy 2020. In support of this area, improved DMC systems 
are needed for providing information on, and attractive finance for, infrastructure projects. An 
important tool to enable the DMCs to increase investments for the development of infrastructure 
will be systems for bringing project sponsors together with investors, both public and private. 
Notable  progress  has  been  achieved  in  developing  such  systems,  financing  infrastructure 
through a variety of mechanisms in countries like India and the Republic of Korea, including 
significant  use  of  public–private  partnership  (PPP).  However,  it  is  important  that  the 
development of PPP projects is supported by a structured and transparent financing framework 
that clearly describes the basis for investment in PPP projects. The Republic of Korea has 
significant experience in implementing PPP systems for urban infrastructure finance over almost 
a decade. This experience, together with other developed country experience, will provide the 
basis for improved systems in DMCs. 
 
4.  The  main  objective  of  this  project  is  to  strengthen  the  capacity  of  DMCs  to  find 
appropriate  financing  for  infrastructure  projects  and  to  strengthen  ADB’s  support  for  such 
activities  and  its  capacity  to  link  into  such  financing.  The  study  will  assess  existing  PPP 
procurement frameworks and their applicability to develop and implement an infrastructure 
financing platform. The TA will also provide the resources to undertake platform development 
and to roll out the platform to selected DMCs.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
5.  ADB’s response to these needs has been to institute a number of activities, including 
this TA project. The impact of the project will be to enhance private sector investments in 
infrastructure  projects  through  PPP  approaches,  and  to  provide  a  platform  providing 
international visibility to investors in public infrastructure projects at all phases. 
6.  Thus,  in  the  context  of  Strategy  2020,  this  TA  will  contribute  to  the  improved 
management of cities of all sizes in DMCs by developing new mechanisms to finance urban 
infrastructure including private sector participation, supporting operations departments’ urban 
sector  operations.  By  providing  platform  systems  to  bring  projects  to  ADB  subsovereign 
operations and to link projects to other public and private cofinancing, the project will support 
the development of ADB’s pipeline. The TA will also improve ADB’s partnership with related 
experts and institutions in the region, and will demonstrate ADB’s character as a regional 
organization supporting innovation in the sector.  
7.  The outcomes of the TA will be to enhance the financing possibilities for subsovereign 
and/or PPP infrastructure projects in Asia, particularly in sectors of urban infrastructure projects 
identified  as  a  priority  under  Strategy  2020  such  as  urban  transport,  solid  waste,  energy 
efficiency, and sustainable wastewater treatment. It will also result in improved knowledge on 
implementation of PPP investments for DMC urban managers. In addition, the TA will support 
ADB’s urban community of practice in strengthening the knowledge of ADB staff in sustainable 
PPP infrastructure provision. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The project uses three components to meet this objective 
 
(i)  Component 1: Review. Conduct a brief review of the salient features of the 
Korean framework for listing and marketing of infrastructure investment and for 
trading investments in infrastructure projects in selected ADB DMCs, specifically 
India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Pakistan, Thailand, and Viet Nam. Document the 
framework and experience across case study countries with a view to providing 
the basis for the design of a model web-based platform to support infrastructure 
investment.  
 
(ii)  Component  2:  Platform  development.  Design  and  construct  web-based 
databases  and  applications  for  project  structuring  and  listing,  together  with 
systems for ADB initiation of subsovereign/PPP projects, incorporating the ability 
to list the various types of greenfield and brownfield projects for use by project 
sponsors and investors collaborating in project structuring. This component will 
also test the platform framework for India, Pakistan, Thailand, and Viet Nam.3 
 
(iii)  Component  3:  Workshop(s). Organize one or more workshop(s) for policy-
makers from DMCs that (a) disseminates the findings of the study, (b) provides 
them the platform, and (c) provides the initial listings for selected infrastructure 
projects. 
                                                 
3  As yet, country specific activities have not been detailed, but ADB will obtain government “no-objection” prior to 
undertaking activities in a country.

3
9.  The consultants will undertake the required detailed tasks, not limited to, but broadly 
outlined hereunder, to address the scope of work. 
 
(i)  Review investment sourcing and structures under the Republic of Korea’s Private 
Participation Initiative Act (1999), rules, regulations, annual plans, guidelines, 
and amendments and other relevant experience. Determine information required 
for  setting  out  procurement  options;  provisions  for  financial/nonfinancial 
government support; and institutional and contractual frameworks for investment, 
construction,  operation,  and  maintenance  of  the  project.  Document  this  in  a 
working paper in a form suitable for translation to system design notes for a web-
based trading platform. Hold discussions in the Republic of Korea and other 
Asian countries as appropriate with the representative industry institutions and 
associations,  beneficiaries,  and  other  industry/citizen  groups  regarding  their 
needs from the platform. The focal countries were chosen because they have (a) 
a framework for PPP in infrastructure projects and some experience therein, (b) 
dedicated PPP agencies to facilitate exchange, and (c) significant potential for 
ADB PPP engagement with the country. 
 
(ii)  Design  and  develop  a  web-based  platform  providing  the  project  information 
required by potential investors in infrastructure projects, encompassing 
(a)  need for the project and demand for services; 
(b)  various levels of preliminary feasibility assessment—technical feasibility, 
broad sizing and costing, environmental and social acceptability, financial 
feasibility, legal and institutional issues, identification of risks; 
(c)  detailed feasibility analysis (value for money test)—analysis of options; 
detailing of preferred project option; analysis of various issues related to 
technical, environmental, social, financial, legal, and institutional aspects; 
(d)  project  structuring  for  private  sector  participation  modality—
bundling/unbundling project components, project construction, operation 
and  management,  examining  what  is  permissible  within  the 
legal/administrative context, examining what will be acceptable politically 
and socially, and indicating how the project can be brought to a bankable 
stage; 
(e)  financial modeling and identification and prioritization of financing options; 
(f)  criteria for potential private investors and systems to obtain their feedback 
on concerns and to incorporate these before the project is bid out; 
(g)  functions  to  support  systematic  project  risk  assessment—covering 
environmental,  social  and  governance,  anti-money  laundering,  climate 
risk, equator principles, and United Nations Environmental Programme 
(UNDP) responsible investment compliance, etc.;  
(h)  procedures  adopted  for  bidding  and  procurement  and  awarding  the 
project; and 
(i)  monitoring and evaluation instruments embedded in the project design to 
ensure adequate feedback that can be used to make course corrections 
and mitigation measures. 
10.  The consultants will also assess the information requirements for, and design systems to 
enable, ADB subsovereign lending and other ADB financing modalities, as appropriate, to feed 
into the platform. They will also assess requirements for the platform to inform ADB operations 
departments as to opportunities for funding.

4  
11.  The long-term outcome will be to increase ADB finance in the urban sector and improve 
knowledge of best practices both for ADB staff and for our DMC clients. The TA will also 
complement ongoing initiatives, such as the Water Financing Program and Energy Efficiency 
Initiative. This will lead to greater efficiency of urban service delivery. RSDD assessments 
based on Operations Evaluation Department (now the Independent Evaluation Department) 
studies4 indicate that there is scope to at least double ADB urban sector lending by 2015. It is 
projected that such an increase in investment would lead to improved services for 200 million 
people—over half of whom are poor. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000. The TA project will be financed on a 
grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund and administered 
by ADB. The TA cost estimate and financing plan is in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The executing agency for the project will be ADB Sustainable Infrastructure Division 
(RSID), which will directly guide and monitor the project. The Korea Development Institute (KDI) 
is proposed as the partner agency for the systems review component of the TA for the following 
reasons: 
(i)  KDI is an autonomous policy-oriented research organization established by the 
Government of the Republic of Korea as an economic think tank on economic 
policy issues. Through its Public Private Infrastructure Investment Management 
Centre,  KDI  operates  Asia’s  only  web-based  infrastructure  investment  portal 
which is the base model platform for this TA. KDI’s hands-on involvement in the 
context of sharing the experience of the Republic of Korea will therefore bring the 
institutional  learning  that  may  be  difficult  for  other  international  consulting 
organizations to provide. 
(ii)  KDI has significant experience in developing and structuring PPPs. In particular, 
KDI has been providing support to the Korean Government on the system and 
methodology  related  to  the  review  and  assessment  of  the  adequacy  of  the 
concession agreements for private investment projects in PPP projects. KDI’s 
work  also  includes  the  development  of  project-related  guidelines  and  legal 
documents on for private investment projects. KDI has developed a significant 
database that can be useful for this project.   
(iii)  KDI  has  also  been  the  nodal  agency  in  the  Republic  of  Korea  engaged  in 
capacity development and dissemination of knowledge related to PPPs. It has 
organized many workshops, conferences, and seminars and has networks with 
many organizations and professionals in other DMCs. It has also implemented an 
ADB-funded knowledge development TA.5 
(iv)  KDI also has indicated it will cofinance the project, contributing its staff inputs.  
14.  Considering the nature of the project and the funding being sought under the Korea      
e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund, KDI is considered knowledgeable and well placed to

meet the objectives of the project. RSDD will engage national consultants required by KDI to 
implement  this  component,  reimburse  expenses  related  to  activities,  and  oversee 
implementation. Chosen countries have an agency fostering PPP that will be the principal 
counterpart and the home of such an infrastructure platform. “Ownership” of the platform by 
these agencies and the capacity to use will be built under the TA. 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 12 months from November 2009 and will require about 
10 person-months of international individual consultants, including an infrastructure finance 
expert and a securities and exchange platform developer. Implementation will also require about 
15 person-months  of  individual  national  consultants  to  support  review  of  current  practice, 
workshop(s), and knowledge dissemination. Consultancy assignments will be divided into two 
groups: one for systems review and one for platform development. Outline terms of reference 
are in Appendix 3. Consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  the  Republic  of  Korea  e-Asia  and  Knowledge  Partnership  Fund  for  the 
Establishment of e-Systems in Support of Infrastructure Finance in Asia, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) project will require inputs from international and national 
consultants drawn from a range of experts, institutions, and organizations. The international 
consultants should (i) have experience in project formulation and institutional investment in 
infrastructure projects in Asia; (ii) be familiar with Asian Development Bank (ADB) financing 
systems for infrastructure and ADB procedures; and (iii) be familiar with software required for 
portal trading systems. The national consultants will provide technical and research assistance 
support for the TA project implementation team and should have strong backgrounds and 
experience in data collection and analysis, and practice in the above areas.  
 
B.  Consultants 
 
1.  Country Systems Assessment (Korea Development Institute) 
2.  The Korea Development Institute (KDI) will manage the country systems assessment—
providing the Republic of Korea inputs to the study, and coordinating national consultants 
providing input to the assessment. It will do the following:  
 
(i)  Review investment sourcing and structures under the Republic of Korea’s Private 
Participation  in  Infrastructure  Act  (1999),  rules,  regulations,  annual  plans, 
guidelines, and amendments and other relevant Asian experience to determine 
information  required  for  setting  out  procurement  options;  provisions  for  
government support; and institutional and contractual frameworks for investment, 
construction, operation, and maintenance of the project. Assess other current 
best  practices  (e.g.,  in  Hong  Kong,  China  and  Singapore)  to  identify  cost-
effective  solutions  to  infrastructure  procurement  and  trading  problems  facing 
urban managers in India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Pakistan, Thailand, and Viet Nam. 
Proceeding to component 2 should depend on the findings of component 1 and 
conduct of the envisaged workshop(s) to discuss the legislative framework and 
the needs from the platform.  
(ii)  Document this review in a working paper in a form suitable for translation to a 
web-based trading platform using a framework developed with inputs from the 
systems consultants (para. 3). Hold discussions in the Republic of Korea and 
other  Asian  countries  as  appropriate  with  the  representative  industry 
institutions/associations,  beneficiaries,  and  other  industry/citizen  groups 
regarding their needs from the platform. Establish appropriate baseline indicators 
for infrastructure investment (including amounts by sector over time, whether 
debt or equity, and foreign participation) for use in ADB’s developing member 
countries (DMCs) and recommend mechanisms to provide suitable inputs for 
monitoring public–private partnership (PPP) activity in the infrastructure sector.  
(iii)  Prepare  a  summary  report,  reviewing  the  information  obtained  in  (i)  and  (ii) 
above, providing inputs to the design note (para. 3). In particular, the review will 
examine the following: 
(a)  Have such platforms used by the Republic of Korea migrated successfully 
outside the Republic of Korea? If not, why? 
(b)  How satisfied are urban managers in cities with this platform? 
(c)  What systems are currently in place in the DMC cities where the platform 
framework is to be tested?

10  Appendix 3 
 
(d)  How  successful  are  these  systems  in  managing  investment  in  urban 
infrastructure? 
(e)  What  costs  would  be  incurred  by  DMC  cities  if  current  infrastructure 
procurement and financing systems are supplemented with the platform 
to be developed under this project? 
(f)  How  compatible  with  ADB  information  technology  systems  are  the 
infrastructure financing platforms currently being used by others? 
 
(iv)  Review  existing  regional  infrastructure  procurement  and  secondary  market 
arrangements, and test proposed platform. Coordinate national consultants in 
India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Pakistan, and Thailand to produce a brief review of 
existing infrastructure procurement and financing systems; and document these 
as  an  input  to  the  systems  consultants  and  for  a  workshop(s)  at  ADB 
headquarters  in  Manila,  Seoul,  or  another  appropriate  venue  in  Asia  for 
presenting the results of the TA to DMCs. Coordinate participating DMCs for 
preparing and presenting case studies on projects requiring funding, which will 
become initial platform listings. The workshop(s) will also discuss how alliances 
between Korean agencies and other DMC agencies can be forged and sustained. 
At this workshop(s) or through another appropriate modality, assist the systems 
consultants to test and document the platform’s applicability for use in India, 
Pakistan, Thailand, and Viet Nam. KDI will provide brief documentation of the 
workshop(s) to disseminate the project learning and platform to DMCs within 5 
months. 
 
2.  Platform  Development  Consultants (2 international consultants, 10 person-
months) 
 
3.  The task of the platform development consultants will be to develop and program the 
online platform, liaising with KDI to deliver the following:  
 
(i)  A framework for KDI review of infrastructure procurement and trading experience 
in DMCs. 
(ii)  Using the results of the KDI review and discussions in the Republic of Korea and 
other Asian countries, design and construct a web-based platform to encompass: 
(a)  need for the project and demand for services; 
(b)  various levels of preliminary feasibility assessment—technical feasibility, 
broad sizing and costing, environmental and social acceptability, financial 
feasibility, legal and institutional issues, identification of risks; 
(c)  detailed feasibility analysis (value for money test)—analysis of options; 
detailing of preferred project option; analysis of various issues related to 
technical, environmental, social, financial, legal, and institutional aspects; 
(d)  project  structuring  for  PSP  modality—bundling  or  unbundling  project 
components, project construction, operation and management, examining 
what is permissible within the legal and administrative context, examining 
what will be acceptable politically and socially, and indicating how the 
project can be brought to a bankable stage; 
(e)  financial modeling and identification and prioritization of financing options; 
(f)  criteria for potential private investors and systems to obtain their feedback 
on concerns and to incorporate these before the project is bid out; 
(g)  functions  to  support  systematic  project  risk  assessment—covering 
environmental,  social  and  governance,  anti-money  laundering,  climate

risk,  equator  principles,  and  United  Nations  Environment  Programme 
(UNDP) responsible investment compliance, etc.;  
(h)  procedures adopted for bidding/procurement and awarding the project;  
(i)  required security features for maintaining confidentiality as required under 
differing country procurement systems; 
(j)  monitoring and evaluation instruments embedded in the project design to 
ensure adequate feedback that can be used to make course corrections 
and mitigation measures; 
(k)  capacity  to  modify  the  platform  to  respond  to  specific  characteristics 
within a national or sectoral market; and 
(l)  mechanisms to train future informants and operators of the systems and 
test these through the workshop(s). 
 
4.  This activity will be divided into two phases—the first developing a design note based on 
the results of the KDI review, and the second the construction of the platform itself to meet the 
performance criteria set out in the design note. 
 
(i)  The consultants will also assess the information requirements for, and design 
systems  to  enable,  ADB  subsovereign  lending  and  other  ADB  financing 
modalities as appropriate to feed into the platform and for the platform to inform 
ADB operations departments as to opportunities for funding. The consultant will 
construct systems linking to ADB’s system and will, at an early stage in the 
contract, consult ADB’s Office of Information Systems and Technology about the 
selection and copyright issues of connection software and technical feasibility of 
trading.  
(ii)  Based on the working paper and workshop(s) presentations/papers, prepare a 
draft final report including appropriate user manuals and training materials. 
(iii)  Incorporate feedback, if any, and prepare the final report. 
 
5.  The consultants will deliver the following reports and outputs: 
 
(i)  Working paper “Platform Design Note,” including comparison of infrastructure 
financing frameworks in the Republic of Korea and other DMCs, to be submitted 
within 2 months of commencement of the assignment. 
(ii)  Web-based connectivity tools to link to ADB’s Office of Information System and 
Technology systems platform using appropriate software, to be submitted within 
4 months of commencement of the assignment. 
(iii)  Draft final report: 10 copies to be submitted within 6 months of commencement of 
the assignment. 
(iv)  Final report: 10 copies to be submitted within 2 weeks of receipt of comments 
(7 months from commencement of the assignment). The final report will also be 
submitted in a form (pdf) suitable for electronic dissemination together with a 
summary PowerPoint presentation. 
 
6.  The platform development consultants will consist of a PPP infrastructure financing 
specialist  familiar  with  the  processes  of  ADB  and  transaction  processing  systems  design 
(5 person-months) and a securities and exchange operations platform specialist familiar with 
managing complex systems development for financial portals (5 person-months). Consultants 
will  be  recruited  as  individual  consultants,  as  set  out  in  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time).

12  Appendix 3 
 
3.  Infrastructure Consultants (various positions-national, 15 person-months) 
 
7.  The national consultants will be familiar with the PPP framework in their respective 
countries  and  have  strong  links  to  government  agencies  engaged  in  PPP  activity  and, 
preferably, to private sector institutions investing in such projects. The main task of the national 
consultants will be to provide high-quality assistance and inputs, backed (where needed) by 
strong data analysis, for KDI review and input to the workshop(s). The tasks of the national 
consultants  will  include  supporting  the  activities  of  international  consultants  in  the  field, 
reviewing documents and literature, collecting data and information, research and analysis (both 
quantitative  and  qualitative),  and  preparing  notes  and  briefs.  The  national  consultants  will 
provide technical, information technology, and administrative support through to completion of 
the TA project, including support to ensuring that appropriate national representatives attend the 
study workshop(s). The national consultants will coordinate with national governments, financial 
institutions,  other  donors,  and  ADB  resident  missions/offices  as  appropriate.  National 
consultants will provide input on national procurement schemes to the platform development 
consultants, including dissemination of case studies, and assessments of platform applicability 
for their particular country, and perform other functions and responsibilities as required. The 
consultants will undertake other tasks as required by the KDI. Consultants will be recruited as 
individual consultants, as set out in ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants.
